title: 113_hr329
content: The Act titled "Strengthening Background Checks Act of 2013" imposes penalties on states that fail to provide data to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. The Strengthening Background Checks Act of 2013 imposes penalties on states for non-compliance with providing records to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System, including withholding 10% of allocated funds if requirements are not met. The Attorney General has the authority to waive certain requirements for states if they provide substantial evidence of efforts to comply with background check regulations, including inability to comply due to legal restrictions. The Attorney General can waive requirements for states if they show efforts to comply with background check regulations, including legal restrictions. The Attorney General can waive state requirements for background check regulations if states show compliance efforts, including legal restrictions. Additionally, the Attorney General can withhold 5 percent of allocated funds under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act for non-compliance. "State laws mandating record provision are outlined in SEC. 107." The State must have laws and policies in place to provide records to the Attorney General, following specific requirements, within two years of the Strengthening Background Checks Act of 2013. Authorization and appropriation for implementation assistance to States are also outlined. The NICS Improvement Amendments Act of 2007 authorizes $125,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2012 to 2015. An appropriation of $125,000,000 is allocated for the grant program under section 103 of the Act. The NICS Improvement Amendments Act of 2007 authorizes $125,000,000 for a grant program under section 103, with $125,000,000 permanently cancelled from unobligated balances in the Department of Justice Assets Forfeiture Fund.
